thread.title: Russian Lender Raises $238 Million in Biggest IPO Since Crimea
thread.title_full: Russian Lender Raises $238 Million in Biggest IPO Since Crimea - Bloomberg Business

author: Alexander Nicholson
title: Russian Lender Raises $238 Million in Biggest IPO Since Crimea
text:
Credit Bank of Moscow raised 13.2 billion rubles ($238 million) selling shares, the biggest initial public offering in Russia in more than a year.
The lender sold shares at 3.62 rubles apiece, giving the bank a market capitalization of 70.2 billion rubles, according to a website statement on Wednesday. The stock will start trading on the Moscow Exchange at 10 a.m.
The sale tested investor appetite for banks as they grapple with official interest rates that have doubled since Russiaâ€™s annexation of Crimea in 2014, which triggered sanctions that blocked companies from global debt markets. The placement was the biggest IPO by a Russian company since Lenta Ltd. raised about $952 million in February 2014.
The dollar-denominated RTS Index has risen 19 percent in 2015, compared with a 2 percent gain for the MSCI Emerging Markets Index.
A fragile truce in Ukraine has driven appetite for Russian assets this year, allowing United Wagon Co. to raise 9 billion rubles in an April IPO, while Lenta sold $225 million of shares in a secondary placement a month earlier. A company linked to billionaire Sergei Galitskiy raised 9.8 billion rubles offering stock in his retailer PJSC Magnit in February.
VTB Capital was the global coordinator and bookrunner for the IPO.
